TextView.text: Carrots and other orange coloured fruits contain Beta-carotene; a type of vitamin A helps the retina and other parts of the eye to function smoothly.
Leafy greens packed with lutein and zeaxanthin—antioxidants that, lower the risk of developing macular degeneration and cataracts.

The egg yolk is a prime source of lutein and zeaxanthin—plus zinc, which also helps reduce macular degeneration risk Citrus and berries These fruits are powerhouses of vitamin C, which has been shown to reduce the risk of developing macular degeneration and cataracts.
Almonds are rich in vitamin E, which slows macular degeneration.
Tuna, salmon, mackerel, anchovies and trout are rich in DHA, a fatty acid found in retina—DHA deficiency is linked to dry eye syndrome.

Tomatoes are rich in carotenoids, including lycopene. The lycopene present in ocular tissues helps prevent light-induced damage to the retina and other areas of the eye. Tomatoes are also an excellent source of vitamin C, another vision protector.
Yellow corn is great source of lutein and zeaxanthin and ½ cup of cooked corn has 1.8 grams of beneficial pigments combined per serving.
